sen.j: 神像（しんぞう）は、信仰の対象となるカミをかたどった彫像、画像である。
sen.e: A sculpture of deities is a statue or a portrait to represent Kami, an object of worship.
A sculpture of deities is a statue or a portrait to represent Kami, an object of worship.
A sculpture of deities is a statue or a portrait to represent Kami, an object of worship.

sen.j: 日本では、神道のカミをかたどった像が多く、道教由来の神の像も見られる。
sen.e: In Japan, many are modeled after Shinto deities, and some originate from Taoistic gods.
In Japan, many are modeled after Shinto deities, and some originate from Taoistic gods.
In Japan, many are modeled after Shinto deities, and some originate from Taoistic gods.

sen.j: 神道においては古くは、カミの依り代（よりしろ）である鏡、玉、剣が崇敬されてきた。
sen.e: In Shinto, traditionally, Yorishiro (an object capable of attracting Kami) such as mirrors, jewels, and swords are worshiped.
In Shinto, traditionally, Yorishiro (an object capable of attracting Kami) such as mirrors, jewels, and swords are worshiped.
In Shinto, traditionally, Yorishiro (an object capable of attracting Kami) such as mirrors, jewels, and swords are worshiped.

sen.j: 偶像崇拝の影響は垂迹思想によるという。
sen.e: Idol worship trend probably comes from the Suijaku theory (Shinto and Buddhist syncretism).
Idol worship trend probably comes from the Suijaku theory (Shinto and Buddhist syncretism).
Idol worship trend probably comes from the Suijaku theory (Shinto and Buddhist syncretism).

sen.j: 神像は神人同形説の信奉者によって製作された。
sen.e: Sculptures of deities were made by believers in anthropomorphism.
Sculptures of deities were made by believers in anthropomorphism.
Sculptures of deities were made by believers in anthropomorphism.

sen.j: ただし全裸ではなく、衣服を着用している。
sen.e: Additionally, they were made not naked but dressed.
Additionally, they were made not naked but dressed.
Additionally, they were made not naked but dressed.

sen.j: 木彫の坐像が多い。
sen.e: Many of them are sedentary statues.
Many of them are sedentary statues.
Many of them are seated statues.

sen.j: 男神像の髪型は角髪または冠をかぶった衣冠装束が多く、女神像は十二単を着用しているものもある。
sen.e: Many sculptures of male deities have a hairstyle of Mizura (wearing one's hair in a bun on each side of the head) or put on a crown; some sculptures of female deities wear Juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

Many sculptures of male deities have a hairstyle of Mizura (wearing one's hair in a bun on each side of the head) or put on a crown; some sculptures of female deities wear Juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

Many sculptures of male deities have a hairstyle of Mizura (wearing one's hair in a bun on each side of the head) or put on a crown; some sculptures of female deities wear Juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

sen.j: 神社に安置される神像は「ご神体」とされて一般に公開されることはあまりなく、寺院における仏像とは対照的である。
sen.e: Since sculptures enshrined in shrines are regarded as "Goshintai" (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity), they are rarely open to the public, which stands a stark contrast to Buddhist statues in temples.

Since sculptures enshrined in shrines are regarded as "Goshintai" (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity), they are rarely open to the public, which stands a stark contrast to Buddhist statues in temples.

Since sculptures enshrined in shrines are regarded as 'Goshintai' (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity), they are rarely open to the public, which stands a stark contrast to Buddhist statues in temples.

sen.j: もと手向山八幡宮の神体。
sen.e: Originally, it was an object of worship enshrined in the Tamukeyama-hachimangu Shrine.
Originally, it was an object of worship enshrined in the Tamukeyama-hachimangu Shrine.

sen.j: 八幡神に菩薩の号を与え、僧形にあらわしたもの。
sen.e: Hachimanshin (God of War) given the title of Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) in the guise of a monk

sen.j: 十二単をまとい、黒髪を垂れ、ほおにえくぼをつくり、眼は玉眼とする。
sen.e: It wears Juni-hitoe; its black hair hangs down, cheeks dimple, and eyes are Gyokugan (eyes made of crystal which were inserted into the head of a wooden Buddhist statue in order to produce a realistic appearance).

It wears Juni-hitoe; its black hair hangs down, cheeks dimpled, and eyes are Gyokugan (eyes made of crystal which were inserted into the head of a wooden Buddhist statue in order to produce a realistic appearance).
